opts.opt:
Birds Apostlebird Australasian Darter Australian Magpie Australian White Ibis Azure Kingfisher Bar-shouldered Dove
Black Bittern Black or dark brown body with yellow patch down the sides of the neck and chest; dark legs.
Black Kite Similar to Whistling Kite.
The Black Kite has V shape tail; the Whistling Kite has a rounded tail.
Black-faced Cuckoo-shrike Blue-faced Honeyeater Blue-winged Kookaburra Brolga Brown Falcon
Brown Goshawk Similar to the Collared Sparrowhawk.
Goshawk has feathers at the top of legs; the Sparrowhawks legs are bare to the body.
Middle toe of the Sparrowhawk is longer than its other toes; the Goshawk toes are equal in length.
Burdekin Duck Bush Turkey Bush-stone Curlew
Collared Sparrowhawk Similar to the Brown Goshawk.
Goshawk has feathers at the top of legs; the Sparrowhawks legs are bare to the body.
Middle toe of the Sparrowhawk is longer than its other toes; the Goshawks toes are equal in length.
Comb-crested Jacana Common Bronze-wing Pigeon Crested Pigeon Crimson Finch Dollarbird Eastern Koel Emu Galah Glossy Ibis Gouldian Finch Great Bowerbird Intermediate Egret Jabiru Little Black Cormorant Little Corella Little Pied Cormorant Magpie Goose Magpie Lark Masked Lapwing
Nankeen Night Heron Dark red-brown back and white-cream underside; back of head black; yellow legs and eyes.
In breeding season, back of the head has long feathers.
Northern Rosella Pacific Baza Pacific Black Duck Pelican Rainbow Bee-eater Red-collared Lorikeet Red-tailed Black Cockatoo Royal Spoonbill Silver-crowned Friarbird Southern Boobook Straw-necked Ibis Sulphur-crested Cockatoo Tawny Frogmouth Torresian Crow Varied Lorikeet Variegated Fairy-wren Wedge-tailed Eagle Whistling Duck
Whistling Kite Similar to the Black Kite.
The Black Kite has V shape tail; the Whistling Kite has a rounded tail.
White-bellied Sea Eagle White-faced Heron White-necked Heron Willie Wagtail Yellow-billed Spoonbill

Dragons Chameleon Dragon Frilled-neck Lizard
Gilbert’s Dragon Similar to Swamplands Lashtail.
Lashtail’s back scales run alongside spine; Gilbert’s back scales run diagonally to spine.
Lally’s Two-lined Dragon Has gular fold (fold of skin underneath the neck).
Snout-vent length 71mm; Tail 200-300% of snout-vent..
Ring-tailed Dragon
Robust Two-lined Dragon Weak gular fold (fold of skin underneath the neck).
Snout-vent length 73mm; Tail length 150-300% of snout-vent.
Swamplands Lashtail Similar to Gilbert’s Dragon.
Lashtails back scales run alongside spine; Gilbert’s back scales run diagonally to spine.
Two-lined Dragon No gular fold (fold of skin underneath the neck). Snout-vent length 55mm; Tail length 230% of snout-vent.
Yellow-sided Two-lined Dragon No gular fold (fold of skin underneath the neck).
Snout-vent length 84mm; Tail length 200-300% of snout-vent..
Fish Archer Fish Barramundi Black Bream Blue Salmon Bony Bream Bull Shark Eel-tailed Catfish Fork-tailed Catfish Freshwater Longtom Largetooth Sawfish Mangrove Jack Saratoga Sleepy Cod Spangled Perch

Frogs
Bilingual Froglet Similar the Remote Froglet without hearing call.
Highly variable colour and pattern.
Distinctive two toned call (see Frog ID App).
Cane Toad
Copland’s Rock Frog Similar to Peter’s Frog. Peter’s Frog has slender digits with small discs; Copland’s Rock Frog has larger discs.
Dahl’s Aquatic Frog Desert Tree Frog
Floodplain Toadlet Similar to Stonemason Toadlet.
DOES NOT have raised line of markings over shoulders and side of body or pale pink colour under the back legs (both seen in Stonemason Toadlet).
Giant Burrowing Frog Green Tree Frog Marbled Frog Masked Frog Northern Dwarf Tree Frog Northern Spadefoot Toad Ornate Burrowing Frog Pale Frog
Peter’s Frog Can be confused with Copland’s Rock Frog.
Peter’s Frog has slender digits with small discs; Copland’s Rock Frog has larger discs.
Remote Froglet Similar to the Bilingual Froglet. Highly variable colour and pattern.
Call similar to longer note of Bilingual Froglet call (see Frog ID App)
Rocket Frog Rockhole Frog
Roth’s Tree Frog Colour regularly changes, often grey, beige or light brown during the day, and darker grey or brown when active at night. Eye silver-grey in lower part, and dark to light rusty red in top section.
Stonemason Toadlet Has raised line of markings over shoulders and side of body. Pale pink colour under the back legs. Similar to the Floodplain Toadlet.
Tornier’s Frog Black stripe starts at snout, narrows before eye, then widens behind eye and ends near arm.
Toes half webbed. Similar to Wotjulum Frog.
Woodworker Frog
Wotjulum Frog Dark stripe starts at snout, narrows before the eye, then widens behind eye to half way along side of body. Toes fully webbed. Similar to Tornier’s Frog.

Geckos Bynoe’s Gecko
Crowned Gecko The Crowned Gecko has large pale patches on its sides. Similar to Pale-striped Ground Gecko.
Fat-tailed Diplodactylus Marbled Velvet Gecko Northern Dtella Northern Spotted Rock Dtella
Pale-striped Ground Gecko Has small pale dots, sometimes forming narrow lines down the sides. Similar to Crowned Gecko.
Spiny-tailed Gecko Zigzag Velvet Gecko

Goannas
Black-headed Monitor Head scales: Supraoculars very small, sharply differentiated from large interoculars.
Black-palmed Monitor First half of tail black, remainder a creamy yellow; palms and soles of feet are black.
Tail more than twice as long as rest of body.
Merten’s Water Monitor Nostrils directed upwards. Ridge along top of tail.
Ridge-tailed Monitor Sand Ridge Goanna
Spotted Tree Monitor Head scales: Supraoculars gradually merging with larger interoculars.

opt.p: Species Photos/Legless Lizards and Sliders/Burton_s Legless Lizard.jpg

opts.opt: Legless Lizards and Sliders Burton’s Legless Lizard Excitable Delma Lesser Robust Fine-lined Slider North-eastern Orange-tailed Slider Northern Hooded Scaly-foot

Mammals Agile Wallaby
Antilopine Wallaroo Males reddish to brown; females reddish but grey on head and shoulders, with pale cheeks.
Ears pale inside and around edge.
Tail is pale and the same thickness all the way along.
Black paws.
Black Rat Brush-tailed Rabbit Rat
Common Planigale Narrow, flattened head .
Females have backward-facing pouch.
Thin tail shorter than body length.
Common Rock Rat
Common Wallaroo Pale grey to brown, black hands and feet, white underneath.
Delicate Mouse Narrow dark brown ring around large eye.
Thin tail slightly longer than body.
Dingo Donkey Dugong Dusky Rat European Cattle
Fawn Antechinus Pale grey body; whitish feet and throat (yellow in males); pale ring around the eye.
Feral Cat Grassland Melomys Horse House Mouse Northern Brown Bandicoot Northern Brush-tail Possum Northern Hopping Mouse Northern Nailtail Wallaby Northern Quoll Pale Field-rat Pig Red-cheeked Dunnart Rock Ring-tail Possum Short-beaked Echidna Short-eared Rock Wallaby Sugar Glider Swamp Buffalo Water Rat
Western Chestnut Mouse Pale chestnut eye ring.
Tail usually shorter than body and has scales on whitish underside.
Shellfish Crayfish Freshwater Crab Freshwater Prawn Green Mudcrab Mussel

Skinks
Bar-shouldered Ctenotus Narrow blackish stripe with no pale edging down the back of juveniles. Stripe is usually is absent or incomplete in adults.
Bar-tailed Bar-lipped Skink Distance between limbs when they are pressed against the body is no more than the length of the arm.
Bauxite Rainbow Skink Two ridges on each scale in the middle of the back.
Common Dwarf Skink First scale above eye (supraciliary) much smaller than second and not touching first supraocular scale (see Guide to animals and plants in SE Arnhem Land). Similar to Northern Dwarf Skink.
Desert Rainbow Skink Elegant Ctenotus Leopard Ctenotus
Lined Fire-tail Skink Pale stripes on sides of the back end at the snout.
Head scales: Supranasal distinct from nasal. Similar to Storr’s Snake-eyed Skink.
Metallic Snake-eyed Skink Northern Bar-lipped Skink Northern Blue-tongued Lizard
Northern Dwarf Skink First scale above eye (supraciliary) similar in size to the second and touching first supraocular scale (see Guide to animals and plants in SE Arnhem Land). Similar to Common Dwarf Skink.
Northern Mulch Skink Limbs widely separated when pressed against the side of the body.
Northern Soil-crevice Skink Ornate Soil-crevice Skink Port Essington Ctenotus
Robust Ctenotus Dark stripe down spine has a thin pale edge. Light stripe from above eye down side of back to halfway down tail. Dark streaks on back legs.
Shaded-litter Rainbow Skink White stripe on upper lip running under eye and past the arm.
Slender Rainbow Skink No prominent white stripe from under eye to ear.
Three moderate sized ridges on each scale of the back.
Spalding’s Ctenotus Three supraocular scales.
Storr’s Snake-eyed Skink Pale stripes on sides of back end above eye.
Head scales: Anterior part of supranasal fused to nasal. Similar to Lined Fire-tail Skink

Snakes Black-headed Python Brown Tree Snake (Venomous) Carpet Python Children’s Python Death Adder (Venomous) Eastern Bandy-bandy (Venomous) File Snake
Greater Black Whipsnake (Venomous) It is larger (1.6m) than the Lesser Black Whipsnake (1.2m). Black or dark brown body with not many facial markings.
Green Tree Snake Keelback
King Brown Snake (Venomous) Each scale has a dark back edge. Eye reddish-brown.
Lesser Black Whipsnake (Venomous) It is smaller (1.2m) than the Greater Black Whipsnake (1.6m). Each scale has a dark edge creating a spotted pattern.
Little Spotted Snake (Venomous) Macleay’s Water Snake (Mildly Venomous) Northern Blind Snake
Northern Brown Snake (Venomous) Large rostral (snout) scale. Blackish mouth lining. Eye dark with orange ring around pupil.
Northern Small-eyed Snake (Venomous) Olive Python
Olive Whipsnake (Venomous) Head has pale edged, dark blotches. Dark streak from corner of eye to back of mouth.
Orange-naped Snake (Venomous) Roper Shovel-nosed Snake (Venomous) Water Python

Turtles
Cann’s Snake-necked Turtle Bottom of shell wide near head; middle scale twice as long as connection between pectoral scales (see Guide to animals and plants in SE Arnhem Land).
Flatback Sea Turtle Green Sea Turtle Hawksbill Sea Turtle
Northern Snake-necked Turtle Bottom of shell narrow near head; middle scale the same length as connection between pectoral scales (see Guide to animals and plants in SE Arnhem Land).
Olive Ridley Sea Turtle Short-necked Snapping Turtle
